entry.title: Using Pyinstrument
entry.content:
Why might you want pyinstrument?

  • It's super easy to use
  • It has great django integration
  • It works with modern python (async/await)
  • Its output is easy to read and understand (if you've tried cprofile + kcachegrind you'll see what I mean!)

Pyinstrument is an easy to use tool which measures how your Python program performs. It's got great integration with Django. With just a couple of small changes to your settings you can start finding and fixing slow parts of your code.

Installing

pip install pyinstrument

Configuring for Django

the docs

Add to your MIDDLEWARE:

    "pyinstrument.middleware.ProfilerMiddleware",

You can profile a page by appending ?profile to a request, or profile all requests by adding PYINSTRUMENT_PROFILE_DIR = 'profiles' to settings.

Other Uses

  • Pyinstrument can profile a script
  • Or wrap any python code

Pyinstrument in bug finding

One of the pages I was profiling was loading fairly fast - but take a look at what's going on here!

There's a save in the middle of our GET request. Most of that time was taken up in updating save indexes (something else to optimmise!) but the concern is why we're actually running activity.save() on something every time we visit the list.

As it turned out, the save was conditional on activity.completion being None. It was supposed to set that... but because of a type comparison bug it was not setting the completion. Therefore the next visit would save again... and again... and again...

The point here is that pyinstrument gave me the right level of detail to go "That's funny..." and quickly identify and fix a otentially serious bug. As to why that save is occuring, that's probably something we want to resolve outside of a request/response cycle.

But that's "a story for another time!"

entry.title: Making a Django App from scratch
entry.summary: Setting up a Django app from scratch
entry.content:
Install django as a user package

pip install --user django

Roll your app

django-admin.py startapp my_app_name

Get it into git

cd my_app_name
git init

Get it into github

Set up your code style for flake8, black, isort etc

Set up your requirements

mkdir requirements
touch requirements/base.in

entry.title: Using Github Actions
entry.content:
Git Actions

Git Actions are a (relatively) new way of doing all sorts of interesting things with your code. Actions can run QA checks, tests, publish packages, create distributable files, and much much more. Actions are configured by adding yaml files into the .github/workflows directory of your repo

Some of the other interesting things you can do: - Install system packages and run command line tools - You can upload files generated by actions (eg whatver you built with dist) as an "artifact" - For testing: you can add any Docker images (postgres, redis etc) to your test run

Here's a simple example file:

name: Pytest

on:
    push:
      branches:
        - "tests/**"
    pull_request:
      branches:
        - master

jobs:

    flake8:
        runs-on: ubuntu-latest

        steps:
        - name: checkout
          uses: actions/checkout@v2
        - name: Set up Python 3.8
          uses: actions/setup-python@v2
          with:
            python-version: 3.8
        - name: Install dependencies
          run: |
            pip install flake8
        - name: run flake8
          run: |
            python -m flake8

This is going to run flake8 on every test run. We're checking out the repo, installing python and flake8, and running flake8. Super easy!

Examples of Steps

Here's steps we can use to run steps to build out our src files - in this case yarn

        - name: node
          uses: actions/setup-node@v2
          with:
            node-version: '14'

        - name: yarn  install
          run: |
            npm install -g yarn
            yarn install
            yarn build

Of course we usually want to install some system packages, which we can do with apt on ubuntu

        - name: Install OS level dependencies
          run: |
            sudo apt-get update
            sudo apt-get install binutils libproj-dev gdal-bin python3-psycopg2

To run prettier, we can use a contributed action. For this action, it's got options to push changes back into the repo if we include an appropriate TOKEN.

        - name: Prettify code
            uses: creyD/prettier_action@v3.1
            with:
                prettier_options: --write src/ !src/tinymce/**
            env:
                GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

entry.title: Setting Up Code QA Tools
entry.summary: Description and configuration of black, isort, flake8 and prettier
entry.content:
Chances are, if you're new to Python programming (or programming in general) you'll find yourself facing comments/suggestions about code style: "Please remove spaces", "Please put imports at top of the file".

Things like that become second nature after a while but even experienced developers get caught out by "code style" issues. While they might not have any effect on how your code runs, keeping a consistent codestyle is really valuable for helping you and others understand what your team wrote when you revisit it later.

One of the best ways to fix code style atrocities and fixed spacing. Removed whitespace commits, is to prevent them in the first place. Here are four of the tools we use in our tech stack to squash these before they get committed to code

  • Flake8: The classic formatter helps you to catch all sorts of unwanted stuff in your code
  • Black: The "opinionated Python formatter".
  • isort: A small library to consistently order your code imports
  • prettier: This one's not for Python; but it will handle your css, markdown, javascript and a ton of other files

Configuring them all

There's a lot of great resources around, I'll just post the 3 main config files which I use in my own projects. We tend to use Django in the backend and riotjs 5 in the frontend.

Black and isort

Black and isort can be configured from a pyproject.toml file. The main things to note are to tell the tools not to dive into and reformat files which are in a virtual env.

pyproject.toml

[tool.isort]
profile = 'black'
skip = ['env']

[tool.black]
line-length = 180
target-version = ['py38']
include = '\.pyi?$'
exclude = '''
/(
  | \.git
  | \.mypy_cache
  | \.tox
  | \.venv
  | \env
  | migrations
)/
'''

flake8

Flake8 can be configured in a few different locations. For our projects we generally ignore line-length and a couple of others

tox.ini

[flake8]
# E501 line length
# W503 break-before-boolean
# E231 is "missing whitespace"
# E203 is not PEP compliant
ignore = E501,W503,E203
exclude = env

prettier

Our prettierrc is still a work in progress. Because we use .riot files, (which are html with a different extension), some systems won't reformat them unless specifically told that they are html.

{
    "printWidth": 140,
    "tabWidth": 4,
    "useTabs": false,
    "bracketSpacing": false,
    "trailingComma": "none",
    "overrides": [
        {
            "files": "*.riot",
            "options": {
                "parser": "html"
            }
        }
    ]
}

Running these

  • invoke flake8 with flake8 . in your repo
  • invoke black with black . in your repo
  • invoke isort with isort . in your repo
  • invoke prettier with prettier --write src to prettifty a "src" folder (note: prettier is quite aggressive... it'll try to reformat all sorts of files! Recommend only running it one folder at a time AFTER running it with --check!)
